Stop asking me 'what' I am â€“ it's dehumanising

By James Clay

People of colour don't owe anyone an autobiographical account of where they're "really" from

Tinder Loving Care

If this catches on any further, I can honestly declare that romance is profoundly dead. Gone are the days of going up and dancing with a girl, or striking up a pleasant conversation at the bar. Winning someone over with your wit and charm, and maybe a well-picked shirt, are forgotten traits of the past.

No man's land

Why is it that so many more girls than boys are getting into university?

Chivalry, it's your round

You already bought the last round when you first met but now you've got a fiver to your name and probably (definitely) an old Chupa Chup in your pocket somewhere... and this is where you ask yourself: when student incomes are more or less equal, is it still right that you are expected to foot the bill?

There's nowt wrong with accents, duck

High school never ends

Size isn't everything

York will never have the demand to be able to rival these big cities' scale and diversity of clubs, however that is not an entirely bad thing.

Setting the record straight

Although it is positive sign that organisations and staff are trying to challenge prejudice and homophobia in schools, there is a need for an approach that further involves students and doesn't scare them away from discussing homosexuality.

Vision's Eton Mess highlights all the worst aspects of student journalism

It all suggests that the journalists who wrote this article were looking for the story, looking for any excuse to link back a complicated set of events to issues of snobbery and race.

Ladette to Lady: the presentation of women in reality TV

Lily Allen: fighting sexism with sarcasm

By parodying recent exhibitions of sexuality, Allen's return to the spotlight successfully tackles the hyper sexualised images of pop stars such as Robin Thicke, Rihanna and Miley Cyrus.

English Literature: going, going, Gove

Whilst sciences and computing are essential for the future, I still cannot comprehend how foolish Gove would be to rid the curriculum of literature.

Embrace York's cheesy nightlife

Don't condemn places for sticky floors and bad music, rather appreciate them for their cheap drinks and comic value.

Do American style degree classifications make the grade?

UK higher education is serious about disruption to our established 200 year old system. Like with so many things, America will in all likelihood continue to increase its influence on the British way of life.

A 'tache is for life, not just for Movember

It is possible that my love of these furry upper-lip caterpillars is purely some unusual fetish that pertains exclusively to me and very few others?

The chastity clothing line that creates victims

The Anti-Rape wear clothing line will only encourage victim blaming and fails to deal with the root of the problem- the rapist.

Volunteer tourism: no good deed goes unpunished

Those who volunteer their time to work with disadvantaged children are often exploited by the organising companies, a practice that needs to end.

Separating personality from politics

To disregard Brand's politics on the basis of his sexism is to disregard John Lennon's peace activism on the basis that he beat his wife. Do the latter make the former any less valuable? Not a jot.

Baking Bad

The sexism is undeniable, but what is even more sexist is that is it Ruby who, in this theorised situation, is criticised for manipulating and seducing with no repercussions on Paul Hollywood.

Support the university strike action

Whilst not every member of staff is perfect, we are extremely lucky to attend a university of a high calibre like York. Both the strike and the manner in which it has been handled it encourage us to support the academic body. Even if you don't, you can't possibly object to the extra day off.

Welcome from your new comment team

One of the aims for this year is to make this section more interactive, to get more of our readers involved in the debate by having them write us responses

Halloween costumes: where do we draw the line?

Stereotypes have always existed but they are only dangerous when people think there is truth in them or discriminate based on them. To ban dressing up as a stereotype gives them importance and gravity that they truly do not deserve.

Money in the Banksy

Brand new revolution smacks of old sexism

He might be a charismatic anti-establishment presence, but for someone seeking social change, he is still propagating the same lazy sexist attitudes so endemic to the system he wants to destroy.

Students turning to sex work sheds light on financial strife

Students turning to sex work shows that more financial support is urgently required.

Don't bar campus drinkers

The proposed alcohol levy will combat anti-social behaviour in town, but just isn't appropriate for campus.

Higher education: privilege or human right?

A Southerner in York

I don't care for regional pride, because I believe the logical extension of these is arbitrary conflict, like the clashing of football firms or religious sects.

York's political apathy

This university's lack of interest in campus politics is a dire shame, yet we are being given the opportunities to make a huge difference to our experiences here.

Remembering Mental Health

We should ensure that the issue of student mental health does not get forgotten.

Sex work: respect choices but provide support where it is sought

York students turning to sex work reveals the strains of student finance.
